reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central element: the paper’s framing that a “big target” (common-sense utopia) vs a “narrow target” (near-best future) matters for how likely we are to get mostly-great futures by default, and that “no easy eutopia” follows from target narrowness. However, the paper explicitly brackets navigation/steering (factors 2–3) and even notes that narrow targets might still be hit via convergence/optimization (and defers that to the next essay), so the critique partly shifts the debate rather than undermining the core claim that eutopia is a narrow target under many plausible value theories. Argumentatively, it asserts (without support) a strong “instrumental convergence of moral progress” thesis and that common-sense utopia is the only reliable mechanism; it also doesn’t engage the paper’s specific reasons for fragility (multiplicative factors, population ethics, digital beings, bounded/unbounded views, etc.) or the paper’s conditioning on “no serious coordinated de dicto optimization.” The key point—that liberal abundance plus reflection could improve the odds of steering toward the narrow target—is plausible, hence moderate correctness, but it does not substantially refute the position as stated. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Common-sense utopia may be the necessary path to discovering the narrow target
